summary: This document is an email chain from September 26-27, 2019, between FBI personnel discussing updates to a victim contact list for the Epstein case. It reveals coordination on victim representation, identification of deceased victims, and attorney assignments.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: Representing a victim (victim ID 20) in the Epstein case, as noted by FBI personnel updating the victim contact list.

persons.name: Robert Josefberg
persons.context: Representing a victim (victim ID 13) in the Epstein case, per the FBI's updated victim list.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Represents a victim and also represents Brad Edwards, as indicated in the FBI's victim list updates.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: An attorney representing a victim (victim ID 23) and is listed twice on the victim contact list. One entry notes he is deceased and needs to be removed.

connections.description: Allred is representing this victim in the Epstein case.
Josefberg is representing this victim in the Epstein case.
Scarola represents attorney Brad Edwards, who is also involved in the case.
Scarola represents a victim in the Epstein case.
Edwards is listed as representing this victim.

events.title: FBI Victim List Coordination
events.description: FBI personnel from New York and another office exchange emails to update and finalize a victim contact list for the Epstein case, noting attorney representations and deceased individuals.

events.title: Follow-up on Victim List
events.description: An FBI Unit Chief follows up on the victim list updates, asking about procedures for deceased victims and their next of kin.

keyFacts: The FBI's Victim Services Division was actively maintaining and updating a victim contact list for the Epstein case in late September 2019.
High-profile attorney Gloria Allred was representing at least one victim (ID 20) in the case.
Attorney Brad Edwards was both representing a victim and was himself listed on the contact list, with one entry noting he was deceased and needed removal.
The correspondence shows procedural questions about whether next of kin of deceased victims are entitled to case information.
